question_details.title: Will legislation be approved by at least one chamber of Congress in 2025 that partially or fully exempts at least one executive branch department, the CIA, or EPA from the Freedom of Information Act?
question_details.description:
This question is synced with an identical question on Metaculus. The original question opened on 2025-01-31 20:49:00 and can be found [here](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/34509). This question will resolve to the same value as the synced question. The original question's background info at this time is below. 

FOIA (5 U.S.C. § 552)

The [<u>Freedom of Information Act </u>](https://ballotpedia.org/Freedom_of_Information_Act)(FOIA) was passed in 1967 to increase government transparency. It requires that, upon request, the U.S. Government and its agencies disclose previously unavailable non-classified information. Journalists and citizen groups have consistently relied on the FOIA to expose government misconduct. For example, activists discovered in the 1980s that the Environmental Protection Agency knew that paper mills were polluting toxic waste into rivers. In 2016, President Obama signed an update to the bill that sought to create greater transparency. The update undid initial exemptions for information about the deliberation of government agencies. It also mandated government agencies to prefer openness when receiving an FOIA request ("presumption of disclosure").

`{"format":"metac_closes_in_period","info":{"post_id":34509,"question_id":34025}}`
question_details.resolution_criteria: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2026, [<u>credible sources</u>](https://www.metaculus.com/faq/#definitions) report that at least one chamber of Congress (House of Representatives or Senate) has approved legislation that partially or fully exempts at least one executive branch department or agency listed in the Fine Print from the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA).
question_details.fine_print:
\- This question will resolve to Yes only if the legislation explicitly exempts at least one executive branch agency or department on our specified list of 17 from FOIA ([<u>5 U.S.C. § 552</u>](https://www.justice.gov/oip/freedom-information-act-5-usc-552)), either in full or in part. This includes new legal exemptions or changes to existing exemptions that limit the applicability of FOIA to specific agencies or departments.

\- Our list of executive branch agencies and departments is the following: Department of Agriculture, Department of Commerce, Department of Defense, Department of Education, Department of Energy, Department of Health and Human Services, Department of Homeland Security, Department of Housing and Urban Development, Department of the Interior, Department of Justice, Department of Labor, Department of State, Department of Transportation, Department of the Treasury, Department of Veterans Affairs, Central Intelligence Agency (CIA), Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).

\- The legislation does not need to become law (i.e., it does not require passage by both chambers or the President’s signature) for this question to resolve as Yes.

\- Amendments to existing laws that add restrictions or requirements will qualify if they meet the above criteria.

Here are the relevant news articles:

**Major Press Outlets Side With GOA in Lawsuit Over ATF Records**
More than two dozen media outlets and journalism associations are supporting Gun Owners of America (GOA) in its lawsuit against the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives (ATF) over the agency’s inadvertent disclosure of documents during a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request. GOA initially filed the FOIA request in 2021 seeking information on the ATF’s use of the FBI’s National Instant Background Check System. After the ATF failed to respond, GOA sued and eventually received some documents, but the agency also disclosed additional materials it claimed were not part of the original request and demanded their deletion. When GOA refused, the ATF obtained a court order prohibiting dissemination of those records. GOA has appealed, and the Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press reports that prominent media organizations—including The Atlantic, Axios, National Public Radio, and The New York Times—have filed an amicus brief with the D.C. Circuit Court of Appeals urging reversal of the lower court’s decision. The brief argues that allowing the government to impose prior restraints on lawfully obtained information, even if inadvertently disclosed, undermines the First Amendment and creates a dangerous precedent that could stifle press freedom. The amici cite the Pentagon Papers and Florida Star v. B.J.F. to assert that truthful information lawfully obtained from the government cannot be suppressed merely because it was disclosed by mistake or could have been withheld under FOIA exemptions. The brief emphasizes that the First Amendment protects the public’s right to access and disseminate information, not just professional journalists. The article notes that while many of these media outlets may misrepresent gun rights, they are correct in defending GOA’s First Amendment rights. The D.C. Circuit previously vacated a similar lower court ruling in January 2025 involving the U.S. Park Police, reinforcing the argument that prior restraints on publication are unconstitutional. The article concludes by criticizing mainstream media for their perceived bias on gun rights while affirming their support for press freedom in this case.

Publish date: November 26, 2025 08:31 PM
Source:[Bearing Arms](https://bearingarms.com/camedwards/2025/11/26/major-press-outlets-side-with-goa-in-lawsuit-over-atf-records-n1230742)

**Transparency & Integrity Act of 2026**
The Transparency & Integrity Act of 2026, introduced in the 117th U.S. Congress during its second session, aims to restore integrity in government through sweeping reforms. The bill establishes real-time disclosure of contributions over $200 within 48 hours, mandates beneficial ownership transparency for PACs, Super PACs, and nonprofits, and bans corporate and federal contractor donations. It introduces democracy vouchers of $200 per voter per cycle, caps individual contributions at $2,000, and guarantees media access for publicly funded candidates. Title III prohibits compensated influence activities—including lobbying, access brokering, and strategic advisory services—by individuals, corporations, or entities, with penalties including up to $10 million in civil fines, 10 years imprisonment, and permanent federal contracting bans. Indirect influence channels such as law firms, PR agencies, think tanks, and trade associations are also restricted. Permitted activities include private citizen communications, congressional testimony, journalism, academic research, whistleblower disclosures, and formal public comments. Title IV mandates criminal and financial background checks, 10 years of tax return disclosure, and psychological fitness evaluations for candidates. Title V creates a public contracting portal with real-time data and imposes a 10-year contracting ban on repeat violators. Title VI promotes electoral fairness through ranked-choice voting, independent redistricting commissions, and making federal election day a national holiday with universal mail-in ballots and paper audit trails. Title VII establishes the Independent Integrity Commission (IIC) with prosecutorial authority and automatic funding equal to 0.05% of federal discretionary spending. Title VIII mandates full congressional oversight of classified expenditures, requiring annual reporting to the Congressional Intelligence Committees and the GAO, prohibiting unaccounted funds, and authorizing annual audits. Violations of classified spending rules carry penalties including removal, fines, and up to 10 years in prison. Title IX introduces a mandatory Integrity Oath for all federal officeholders, requiring candidates to affirm that they will not knowingly make false statements or engage in deception, with consequences including immediate removal, permanent disqualification, $5 million civil penalties, up to 10 years imprisonment for violations causing harm, and forfeiture of pensions. The bill is grounded in constitutional authority under Article I, Sections 4 and 8, and takes effect on January 1, 2027.
Original language: en
Publish date: November 26, 2025 03:22 PM
Source:[Medium.com](https://medium.com/@fads-haycock-06/transparency-integrity-act-of-2026-3b7f0cdaf5eb)

**US Congress approves release of Epstein files, set to send bill to Trump**
The U.S. Congress passed the Epstein Files Transparency Act, requiring the Department of Justice (DOJ) to release all unclassified records, documents, communications, and investigative materials related to Jeffrey Epstein’s investigation and prosecution. The bill passed the House of Representatives 427-1 and was unanimously approved by the Senate, with the lone 'no' vote from Republican Representative Clay Higgins, who argued the bill could harm innocent individuals. The legislation mandates that the documents be made publicly available in a searchable and downloadable format, while allowing the DOJ to withhold information that could jeopardize active investigations or reveal victims’ personal details. President Donald Trump, who initially dismissed the Epstein controversy as a 'hoax' and opposed the release, has stated he will sign the bill into law. The case has drawn national scrutiny due to Epstein’s high-profile connections, including former U.S. President Bill Clinton, Prince Andrew, Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Barak, and Harvard University’s former president Larry Summers, who recently apologized for his ties. Survivors, including Jena-Lisa Jones, who was 14 when she met Epstein, spoke publicly at the Capitol, calling for accountability. Trump’s past comments, including calling a reporter 'piggy' on Air Force One, drew widespread criticism from media figures and family members, with CNN’s Jake Tapper calling the remarks 'disgusting and completely unacceptable' and Trump’s niece Mary Trump labeling them 'wildly inappropriate and despicable'. The DOJ already has the authority to release the files without congressional approval.

Publish date: November 26, 2025 09:22 AM
Source:[news24](https://www.news24.com/world/us-congress-approves-release-of-epstein-files-set-to-send-bill-to-trump-20251126-0562)

**Patients' group presses Trump to take on health-care 'fat cats,' demand real price transparency**
The nonprofit patient advocacy group PatientsRightsAdvocate.org (PRA), led by founder Cynthia Fisher, is urging President Donald Trump to enhance healthcare price transparency by empowering patients, employers, and unions with full access to healthcare claims, payments, and fee details through the Department of Labor. Fisher emphasized that placing control of healthcare dollars in the hands of Americans—not insurance companies or private equity 'fat cats'—is essential for restoring fairness and accountability. She specifically called on Trump to support the Patients Deserve Price Tags Act, introduced by Senators Roger Marshall (R-KS) and John Hickenlooper (D-CO), which mandates hospitals to disclose actual prices for approximately 300 services and provide itemized bills. This effort builds on Trump’s February executive order requiring the Treasury, Labor, and Health and Human Services departments to enforce transparency rules, including uniform pricing across hospitals and insurers. Despite uncertainty over the release timeline of Trump’s upcoming healthcare proposal—potentially as early as November 25, 2025—the issue remains a top White House priority. The push comes amid political negotiations over extending Affordable Care Act subsidies, which expired in October 2025 and remain a point of contention. A September 2025 poll by Echelon Insights found that nearly 90% of U.S. voters support regulations requiring upfront disclosure of exact healthcare prices. Republican strategist David Kochel stated that implementing such transparency would be a 'game-changer' for the 2026 election, shifting the healthcare narrative and rebuilding public trust by addressing surprise medical bills and hidden pricing.

**FBI Strengthens Security at Epstein Archive Amid Conspiracy Theories and New Transparency Law**
The FBI has deployed armed agents to guard the Central Records Complex in Virginia, the facility housing two billion pages of documents related to the Jeffrey Epstein case, due to heightened concerns over theft and sabotage. This move followed online speculation on Reddit and other social media platforms about protests and potential direct actions to access the files, including claims that politically sensitive names might be 'cleaned' from the documents. Some users questioned when protests would escalate into direct action. According to internal sources cited by Bloomberg, FBI agents typically based in Washington, D.C., were temporarily reassigned to Virginia to strengthen security. The 23,000-square-meter complex underwent a comprehensive review from March to May, during which FBI agents, FOIA officials, and internal verification staff applied nine exemptions under the Freedom of Information Act to determine what could be released. The documents, covering nearly two decades of federal investigations, include testimonies, prosecutorial records, classified materials, emails, internal communications, and grand jury materials. The review was initially concluded by Attorney General Pam Bondi and the FBI in summer 2025, who stated no further documents would be published. However, the U.S. House of Representatives passed the Epstein Files Transparency Act with 427 votes in favor and one against, mandating the Department of Justice to release all non-classified documents in digital, searchable format within 30 days. President Donald Trump signed the law on Wednesday. The law allows the government to withhold documents if their release could compromise ongoing investigations. Mark Epstein, Jeffrey Epstein’s brother, claimed in an interview with NewsNation that the files would be manipulated to remove 'Republican names,' citing an 'affordable source' and directly accusing the FBI director. Although no evidence supports this claim, the statement fueled conspiracy theories. The House Oversight Committee recently released thousands of emails from Epstein’s personal archive, revealing contacts with both Republican and Democratic politicians, including Bill Clinton and former Treasury Secretary Larry Summers. Epstein’s emails included claims that he was 'the only one who could destroy them' and referenced Donald Trump. Marjorie Taylor Greene, a prominent figure in the MAGA movement and a longtime proponent of Epstein-related conspiracy theories, announced she would not seek re-election in 2026. She had been a leading advocate for the transparency law and has long accused the government of censorship and interference. Her reasons for stepping down were not disclosed. On social media, Trump labeled Greene a 'traitor' and said she 'has gotten worse' since he stopped answering her endless calls.

Source:[Il Messaggero](https://www.ilmessaggero.it/mondo/i_file_segreti_di_epstein_blindata_la_sede_archivio_fbi_alto_rischio_di_furto-9205073.html)

**Government push to unseal court records offers clues about what could be in the Epstein files - The Boston Globe**
The U.S. Justice Department is pushing to unseal court records related to Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell, complying with the Epstein Files Transparency Act, a law passed by Congress and signed by President Donald Trump. The law mandates the public release of Epstein and Maxwell investigative materials in a searchable format by December 19, 2025. The Justice Department submitted a four-page filing listing 18 categories of material it seeks to release, including grand jury transcripts, police reports, photographs, and videos from investigations by the Palm Beach, Florida, police and the U.S. attorney’s office in the mid-2000s. The department is coordinating with survivors and their lawyers to redact sensitive information, including identities and sexualized images. U.S. District Judge Paul A. Engelmayer in New York ordered the government to provide detailed descriptions of the materials to inform victims, as he did not preside over Maxwell’s trial but was assigned the case after Judge Alison J. Nathan’s elevation. Judge Richard M. Berman, overseeing Epstein’s 2019 sex trafficking case, gave the department until Monday to submit detailed descriptions of the records it intends to make public. In August, both judges previously denied requests to unseal grand jury transcripts, ruling such disclosures are rarely permitted. The Justice Department is now arguing that the new law overrides prior restrictions. Tens of thousands of pages of Epstein-related records have already been released through civil lawsuits, Freedom of Information Act requests, and public disclosures. In 2024, a Florida judge released about 150 pages from a 2006 state grand jury investigation. Last week, the Justice Department moved to unseal federal grand jury transcripts from the same investigation, citing the new law.

Title IX introduces a mandatory Integrity Oath for all federal officeholders, requiring candidates to affirm that they will not knowingly make false statements or engage in deception, with consequences including immediate removal, permanent disqualification, $5 million civil penalties, up to 10 years imprisonment for violations causing harm, and forfeiture of pensions. The bill is grounded in constitutional authority under Article I, Sections 4 and 8, and takes effect on January 1, 2027.

**Stalled CIPA Reform Leaves Businesses to Face Compliance Alone**
California lawmakers concluded their 2025 legislative session without passing Senate Bill 690, which would have created a 'commercial business purpose' exemption to the California Invasion of Privacy Act (CIPA), leaving businesses without legislative clarity on compliance. CIPA, originally enacted in 1967 to prevent telephone wiretapping, has been repurposed to challenge digital tracking tools such as Google Analytics, Meta Pixel, and session replay software, with plaintiffs arguing these tools 'intercept' digital communications without consent. Courts have not definitively ruled on whether these tools violate CIPA, but many have allowed claims to proceed, exposing businesses to statutory damages of $5,000 per user. SB 690 passed the Senate but stalled in the Assembly Judiciary Committee due to competing priorities and the need for further discussion among privacy advocates, industry groups, and consumer-rights organizations. In the absence of reform, businesses face ongoing litigation risk, with plaintiffs filing frequent boilerplate lawsuits based on the use of common website tools. To mitigate risk, companies are advised to conduct comprehensive privacy audits, ensure affirmative opt-in consent via clear banners, update privacy disclosures in plain language, strengthen vendor agreements with privacy clauses, implement role-based data access controls, train internal teams on data practices, and review insurance coverage—many of which exclude statutory privacy violations. Even successful defenses may result in reputational harm due to public framing of claims as 'consumer privacy' issues. Observers expect SB 690 or a similar bill to be reintroduced in the next session. Until then, CIPA compliance has become a cross-functional business imperative requiring proactive measures, transparency, and meticulous consent practices to avoid costly litigation and demonstrate good-faith compliance.

**Obama did not sign a law allowing propaganda in the U.S.**
The article refutes the claim that former President Barack Obama signed a law in 2012 that legalized government propaganda in the United States. According to the Associated Press, in 2013 Obama signed an amendment to the U.S. Information and Educational Exchange Act of 1948, commonly known as the Smith‑Mundt Act. The amendment lifted restrictions that previously barred the domestic dissemination of material produced by the U.S. Agency for Global Media (UAGM), the agency that runs Voice of America and Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty. The change allows Americans to request and access UAGM content, but it does not permit the agency to create programming specifically for U.S. audiences or market it to them. The article cites Gabe Rottman, director of the Reporters Committee’s Technology and Press Freedom Project, who explained that "Even upon request, if I wanted to get it through FOIA, for instance, they couldn't do it. The amendment changed that." It also quotes Weston Sager, an attorney, who said the previous law created a "de facto ban on the domestic dissemination of materials originating from the State Department." Emily Metzgar, professor at Indiana University, noted that the original 1948 ban was intended to protect the nascent U.S. broadcast industry, not to shield the public from propaganda. The article reports that the UAGM operates with an annual budget of $805 million and oversees five media networks that reach millions abroad. The claim that Obama "repealed a ban on government propaganda" is therefore false, as the amendment only eased restrictions on access, not on the creation or marketing of content to U.S. audiences.

summary: All experts converge on a very low probability that either chamber of Congress will approve legislation in 2025 that partially or fully exempts any major executive branch department, the CIA, or the EPA from the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA). Across legal, political science, legislative affairs, public administration, and governance perspectives, the experts agree that the historical base rate for such exemptions is extremely low. The recent legislative trend, including the overwhelming passage of the Epstein Files Transparency Act, underscores strong bipartisan momentum towards increased transparency rather than heightened secrecy. Additional factors suppressing the likelihood include robust press and civil society opposition, high electoral and reputational costs for lawmakers, and the lack of any pending or advancing bills with exemption language as of late November 2025. While some mention possible tail-risk scenarios—such as a high-profile security breach prompting a late-emerging emergency exemption, or a stealth amendment tacked onto a must-pass bill—there is no direct evidence of such movements in either chamber. Minor regulatory rollbacks at the agency level (e.g., EPA's changes to expedited FOIA processing) do not meet the resolution criteria and have been pursued as regulatory, not statutory, changes. Final probability estimates among forecasters cluster between 2% and 6%, with consensus that the outcome is highly improbable absent an extraordinary, last-minute event.
